user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of digest_update:
```c
_MHD_static_inline void
digest_update (struct DigestAlgorithm *da,
               const void *data,
               size_t length)
{
  mhd_assert (! da->uninitialised);
  mhd_assert (da->algo_selected);
  mhd_assert (da->ready_for_hashing);
#ifdef MHD_MD5_SUPPORT
  if (MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_MD5 == da->algo)
    MHD_MD5_update (&da->ctx.md5_ctx, (const uint8_t *) data, length);
  else
#endif /* MHD_MD5_SUPPORT */
#ifdef MHD_SHA256_SUPPORT
  if (MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_SHA256 == da->algo)
    MHD_SHA256_update (&da->ctx.sha256_ctx, (const uint8_t *) data, length);
  else
#endif /* MHD_SHA256_SUPPORT */
#ifdef MHD_SHA512_256_SUPPORT
  if (MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_SHA512_256 == da->algo)
    MHD_SHA512_256_update (&da->ctx.sha512_256_ctx,
                           (const uint8_t *) data, length);
  else
#endif /* MHD_SHA512_256_SUPPORT */
  mhd_assert (0);   /* May not happen */
#ifdef _DEBUG
  da->hashing = true;
#endif
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
MHD_SHA512_256_update (&da->ctx.sha512_256_ctx,
                           (const uint8_t *) data, length);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The call itself does not use any <string.h> function, so Rule 21.17 is not directly violated by this fragment. A violation could occur if either (a) the caller passes a length greater than the actual size of the object pointed to by data (causing any reader—including MHD_SHA512_256_update—to read out of bounds), or (b) MHD_SHA512_256_update internally calls a <string.h> function (e.g. memcpy/memmove/memset/str* etc.) with the provided pointer/length and that length exceeds the buffer. If neither of those situations can occur (i.e. length correctly reflects the object size and the internal implementation uses the pointer/length safely), then Rule 21.17 is not violated.
